docs.lead_paragraph: Thirty-eight million Medicare beneficiaries will soon be flooded with information about new health insurance options, and most of them are likely to be thoroughly confused, consumer advocates, members of Congress and Medicare officials say. The new options were created by Congress last year to give beneficiaries a wider variety of choices, like those available to many workers in private industry who receive insurance coverage from their employers.

headline.main: NEW HEALTH PLANS DUE FOR ELDERLY

docs.abstract: Goverment plans extensive education and publicity campaign to explain confusing new Medicare options created by Congress last year to provide wider choice of health care plans; will send beneficiaries new handbook with detailed description of options; says 'focus groups' of beneficiaries who tested materials, including well-educated people, often found choices overwhelming; table of main alternatives (M)
docs.snippet: Thirty-eight million Medicare beneficiaries will soon be flooded with information about new health insurance options, and most of them are likely to be thoroughly confused, consumer advocates, members of Congress and Medicare officials say.    The...

docs.lead_paragraph: Unable to hire enough teachers, the Dallas school board voted last month to lure them with $1,500 signing bonuses. Corporate recruiters paid out much larger bonuses -- averaging $17,500 -- to Cornell's business school graduates. Even Burger King has got into the bonus game, offering $5,000 in some cities to hire away restaurant managers from rival fast-food chains. The signing bonus is proliferating in America, and growing ever larger as employers bid for scarce workers. A recruiting tool that had been limited to upper-level managers, highly skilled technicians and athletes, it is spreading today to many others, even civil servants. The Labor Department, for example, is for the first time offering a bonus of up to $4,000 to attract young economists.

headline.main: Signing Bonus Now a Fixture Farther Down the Job Ladder

docs.abstract: Hiring bonus is proliferating in United States, growing ever larger and being offered farther down job ladder as employers bid for scarce workers; appears to be flourishing because employers have shifted some of bargaining from wages to less costly one-time payments; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Unable to hire enough teachers, the Dallas school board voted last month to lure them with $1,500 signing bonuses. Corporate recruiters paid out much larger bonuses -- averaging $17,500 -- to Cornell's business school graduates. Even Burger King has...

docs.lead_paragraph: Alan C. Greenberg bettered his own life by becoming rich on Wall Street, and yesterday he gave away $1 million of that money to better the lives of other aging men in a very specific way: He will pay for Viagra prescriptions for people who cannot afford them. ''I guess you could say I'm kind of into basics,'' said Mr. Greenberg, 70, the chairman of Bear, Stearns Companies, who received a $20 million bonus last year. ''And I think it's something that will give a lot of pleasure to a lot of people.''

headline.main: $1 Million Gift for New Charity Case: the Viagra-Needy

docs.abstract: Alan C Greenberg, 70-year-old chairman of Bear Stearns, announces he will pay for Viagra prescriptions for people who cannot afford new impotence drug; New York's Hospital for Special Surgery, designated to oversee gift, seems dizzily baffled by offer (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Signs developed today that the Senate's weeks-long impasse on anti-smoking legislation might be broken. The Senate voted, 52 to 46, for a Republican amendment to use some of the money that would be raised from higher cigarette prices on drug abuse programs. The vote was the first on the legislation in three weeks, and plans were made to vote on Wednesday on proposals to use other money from the tobacco legislation for income-tax cuts.

headline.main: Logjam on Bill To Cut Smoking Starts to Unclog

docs.abstract: Senate's weeks-long impasse on anti-smoking bill comes unstuck during series of private meetings that follow unsuccessful Democratic move to cut off debate; Senate, 52-46, approves Republican amendment to use some of money raised from higher cigarette prices on drug abuse programs; vote is set on proposal to use other money from bill for income-tax cuts; Sen Trent Lott, Pres Clinton and Sen John McCain, bill's chief sponsor, say progress is possible; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Signs developed today that the Senate's weeks-long impasse on anti-smoking legislation might be broken.    The Senate voted, 52 to 46, for a Republican amendment to use some of the money that would be raised from higher cigarette prices on drug abuse...

docs.lead_paragraph: States have an unalterable duty to return other states' fugitives, the Supreme Court ruled today in a unanimous opinion that gave the New Mexico Supreme Court no choice but to extradite an escaped parolee whom the state court had deemed to be a ''refugee from injustice'' in the Ohio prison system. Even accepting as ''credible'' the fugitive's testimony that he faced serious threats of injury at the hands of prison officials if returned to custody in Ohio, the Court said, ''this is simply not the kind of issue that may be tried in the asylum state.''

headline.main: Supreme Court Roundup; Right of States to Extradite Fugitives Is Upheld

docs.abstract: Supreme Court rules unanimously that states have unalterable duty to return other states' fugitives; agrees with New Mexico that it must extradite prisoners' rights activist Timothy Reed, escaped parolee NM court sought to protect as 'refugee from injustice' in Ohio prison system; Court, 5-4, rules Federal law that imposes five-year mandatory sentence on anyone who carries firearm in connection with narcotics crime covers person traveling in car with gun in locked glove compartment or trunk; Justice Stephen G Breyer writes majority opinion; Court agrees to decide whether Federal civil rights law can be used to challenge official actions that place waste disposal and other environmentally undesirable installations disproportionately in communities with large minority populations; case involves suit by residents of Chester, Pa, largely black city, against state officials; Court rules unanimously that parent company can be held responsible for costs of cleaning up subsidiary's toxic waste site if parent company was directly responsible for operation of site; ruling comes in Environmental Protection Agency suit against company now known as Bestfoods; Court refuses to hear appeal by 84,000 General Motors retirees challenging GM's right to charge for health benefits it had promised to provide free to retirees (M)
docs.snippet: States have an unalterable duty to return other states' fugitives, the Supreme Court ruled today in a unanimous opinion that gave the New Mexico Supreme Court no choice but to extradite an escaped parolee whom the state court had deemed to be a...

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Tobacco Blues'' is a fresh, humanizing approach to a subject that has been thoroughly demonized in recent years. In answer to the question, ''Can good people grow tobacco?,'' the producers, Christine Fugate and Eren McGinnis, visit with four Kentucky families who bear no resemblance to the cigarette executives who have come to personify the ills of smoking: it's innocence by dissociation. In case you were really wondering, yes, of course good people grow tobacco. These hands-on farmers represent family values, parents and offspring working hard to make a living from their state's main cash crop. They differ over the virtuousness of growing tobacco (most seem to find smoking distasteful), and any of them could stand in as wholesome images of down-home Americana.

headline.main: When Good People Grow a Dangerous Plant

docs.abstract: Walter Goodman reviews Tobacco Blues, documentary in POV series on PBS (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Do not be fooled by the virtuous grins on all those celebrities with the white mustaches. The question ''Got Milk?'' and its corollaries ''How much?'' and ''At what price?'' are fueling what economists call the most contentious, most political battle over agricultural policy in the East, if not the nation. The fight involves Mark Duffy's dairy farm -- the home of cows named Oprah and Cher -- 20 miles northwest of Boston. It has already burst through a score of other statehouses and is expected to flare in the New York Legislature this week. And it will soon play itself out in Washington, pitting East against Midwest, farmers against dairy processors, those who want to preserve farm land against those who want to preserve lower milk prices.

headline.main: Fight on Milk Prices Is Making Its Way to Capital

docs.abstract: Fight over milk prices has already burst through score of statehouses, is expected to flare in New York State Legislature and soon play itself out in Congress; at issue is Federally-authorized compact among six New England states that guarantees their dairy farmers higher price for milk for drinking than one set under Federal support system; compact, which went into effect last July, is meant to shore up region's remaining dairy farms; opponents include advocates for consumers and poor, groups of dairy processors and Midwestern farmers, who fear rise in New England milk output could hurt prices for milk outside region; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Janice Davocato's devotion to her disabled mother has wiped out her savings and turned her into a seven-day-a-week workhorse. Her mother, Sylvia Davocato, fell in her South Philadelphia row house in 1986 and broke a leg. She ended up with severe gangrene and a near-fatal blood infection. When she left the hospital, it was in a wheelchair, with a catheter. She is still in a wheelchair.

headline.main: Families Bear a Bigger Share of Long-Term Care for the Frail Elderly

docs.abstract: Some elderly people and their families are being caught in gap between cost of long-term medical care and limited amount of Government aid to pay for it; experts say that as baby boomers age over next 30 years and over-85 population grows particularly fast, need for such care will only escalate; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Universal health care is a reality in one part of the United States: prison. By law, inmates are guaranteed medical treatment. And with the ranks of prisoners rising an average of 8 percent every year since 1990, providing that treatment is an expensive proposition. To control costs and improve security, a handful of states are trying out telemedicine -- health care via telecommunications. With government agencies, managed-care providers and legislators watching, these programs are serving as a proving grounds for broadening the use of telemedicine.

headline.main: Telemedicine Getting a Test in Efforts to Cut Costs of Treating Prisoners

docs.abstract: Handful of states are testing health care via telecommunications to control costs and improve security of treating prisoners; such programs serve as proving grounds for broadening use of telemedicine; University of Texas telemedicine program is nation's oldest and largest; saves about $300,000 a year in prisoner transportation costs alone; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Universal health care is a reality in one part of the United States: prison.    By law, inmates are guaranteed medical treatment. And with the ranks of prisoners rising an average of 8 percent every year since 1990, providing that treatment is an...

docs.lead_paragraph: Sitting on the ground beside her hut, Bangon Phailak chopped up wild plants for lunch and pondered a wrenching question. What does her 4-year-old daughter need more, food or a mother?

headline.main: Asia Feels Strain Most at Society's Margins

docs.abstract: First of two articles, The Human Crisis, discusses effect of Asian financial crisis on poor people in Ban Wan Yai and other Thai villages; most prominent victims of crisis have been humbled tycoons in big cities, but they are neither most common victims nor most desperate; worst off are people who are already at margins of society--those who had almost nothing before and who have even less now; experts predict that crisis will result in increases in malnutrition and death rates; say legacy of crisis will be felt long after region's economies improve; map; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Sitting on the ground beside her hut, Bangon Phailak chopped up wild plants for lunch and pondered a wrenching question.     What does her 4-year-old daughter need more, food or a mother?
